document.title: Meetings

section.docs: Meetings are controlled by a user. They do not need to have anyone coming to the meeting. Users and contacts can be added to meetings. You invite people by sending their email address. The server will conect the dots to associate the users and contacts. If no one can be found matching the email, then a new contact will be created for you to fill in their information. The server will send invitations via email. Invitations are handled individually. The meeting's organizer will be notified of acceptance and rejections. The organizer can also reschedule or cancel the meeting. If the meeting is rescheduled, all the people will be notified and be asked to reconfirm. Refer to the invitation section for managing individual invitations.

section.title: Routes & Permissions
section.docs:
* `POST /meetings` * `GET /meetings` * `GET /meetings/:id` * `PUT /meetings/:id` * `DELETE /meetings/:id` * `PUT /meetings/:id/reschedule` * `PUT /meetings/:id/cancel`
### Scoping
1. You are in charge of the meeting 2. You are invited to the meeting 3. Any of the invited contacts are assigned to you 4. You are following any of the invited contacts 5. You are an admin

document.section:
### Rescheduling, Cancelling, and Deleting
These are all different actions. Rescheduling is a special update. It works the same way as the regular `PUT /meetings/:id` route except will send out notifications to everyone regardless of if the time changed or anything like that. Cancelling works the same way. You can always reschedule a cancelled meeting. A meeting will continue to exist in the system if it's cancelled. Deleting a meeting will remove it from the system entirely and **will not** send any notifications. It is up to you to decide which functionality to use by a use case by use case basis.

You can add more people to the meeting one the `POST` and `PUT` routes. Specify a `invite` parameter which contains an array of valid email addresses. Invitations will be created and notifications sent out by the server. You are not allowed to create invitations manually. If you want to invite more people to an existing meeting use the `PUT /meetings/:id` route with a `invite` parameter.

section.title: Format
section.docs:
topic
Required
Text describing the meetings purpose
starts_at
Required
Time when it starts
ends_at
Required
Time when it ends
location
Can be an address, can be anything. Example: the office, or 123 Example St.
user
ID for the user managing this meeting
contacts
IDs for all the invited contacts
users
ID's for all the invited users including the organizer
activities
ID's for all activites in the meeting's feed
invitations
All the invitations for the meeting. See the invitation section for more details
You can specify the `invite` parameter to send invitations.
